Nyari N, Singh D, Kakkar K, Sharma S, Pandey SN, Dhole TN. Entomological and serological investigation of Japanese encephalitis in endemic area of eastern Uttar Pradesh, India.

Abstract
BACKGROUND & OBJECTIVES:
Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), a mosquito borne pathogen, is one of the major causes of viral encephalitis in eastern Uttar Pradesh, India. The objective of this work was to evaluate the entomologically based virological surveillance of Japanese encephalitis (JE) in the highly endemic area of eastern Uttar Pradesh.

METHODS:
The study was carried out during September 2010 - March 2013 in Gorakhpur district of Uttar Pradesh. A total of 251 adult mosquito pools and 64 water samples containing larvae were collected from the District of Gorakhpur. Water pH, turbidity, and oxygen level were analyzed for vector breeding index (BI). In addition, 393 serum/cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) samples of acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) suspected cases were collected from the district hospital.

RESULTS:
The various _Culex_ species found included, _Cx. quinquefasciatus_ (26 percent), _Cx. vishnui_ (22 percent), _Cx. pseudovishnui_ (21 percent), _Cx. tritaeniorhynchus_ (13 percent), _Cx. whitmorei_ (9 percent), and _Cx. gelidus_ (8 percent). Highest minimum infection rate (MIR) was calculated for _Cx. tritaeniorhynchus_ (2.32), followed by _Cx. vishnui_ (1.98) and _Cx. pseudovishnu_i (0.71). All the larvae samples were negative for JEV. The mean number larvae of _Cx. tritaeniorhynchus_ and _Cx. pseudovishnui_ was negatively correlated with pH (r = - 0.45 and r = - 0.63) and turbidity (r = - 0.30 and r = - 0.37). In contrast, positive correlation was observed in case of _Cx. quinquefasciatus_. A total of 41 clinical samples were found positive for JEV by IgM ELISA. The rainfall was significantly associated with Japanese encephalitis incidence and showed positive correlation to disease transmission (p = 0.02, r = 0.66).

INTERPRETATION & CONCLUSION:
The findings showed the rapid dissemination of JEV within a population, facilitated by different species of _Culex_ in the region. As JE is a vaccine-preventable disease, an immunization programme, an effective vector control strategy, and application of standard hygiene practices in these endemic areas could result in a considerable reduction in morbidity and mortality due to JE.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED-mail
<promed@promedmail.org>

[The Gorakhpur district of Uttar Pradesh state has been an active focus of JE cases annually. The above study identifies the major mosquitoes involved in transmission of the virus in this region. Vaccination is an effective measure for prevention of JEV, as the above report indicates. Vector control is more difficult, and the report does not indicate which approaches might be effective.

The report indicates that of the 393 CSF samples tested, presumably from encephalitis cases, only 41 were positive for JEV. That raises the same question that has arisen in many previous reports about the etiology of the non-JE cases. The encephalitis picture in northeastern India is complicated. The JE virus etiology of some previously reported encephalitis cases has been confirmed by laboratory tests. However, many cases go undiagnosed, or JE virus infection is ruled out, and other etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, lychee consumption, sun stroke, and enterovirus infection have been proposed. Ardeid birds (heron family) are reservoir hosts.

http://echoofindia.com/jalpaiguri-anti-encephalitis-vaccination-jalpaiguridist-start-nov-30-99084


In a bid to stop the spread of Japanese encephalitis disease in Jalpaiguri, the district health department is all set to start an anti-encephalitis vaccination drive across the region from 30 Nov [2015]. The department aims to vaccinate 13 lakh [1 300 000] people across the district during the month-long campaign. The vaccination will be given to people within the ages of 15-65 years.

Notably, acute encephalitis or Japanese encephalitis disease have taken 30 lives in 2014 in Jalpaiguri District, while more than 300 people were diagnosed with the disease. This year [2015], the district has recorded 20 deaths so far, with 100 registered cases. Last year [2014], the department had provided anti-encephalitis vaccine to children below the age of 15 years and elderly above 65 years in Mal Subdivision and Nagarkatta. This year [2015], the department will set up camps in Raiganj, Jalpaiguri Sadar, Mainagudi, Mateli Block, Jalpaiguri, Dhoopgudi Municipality and Siliguri Municipality areas.

District chief medical officer Dr. Prakash Mrigha said that the anti-encephalitis vaccination campaign will be started from Jalpaiguri DM's office this coming Monday [30 Nov 2015]. "It will take an entire month to reach the target of vaccinating 13 lakh [1 300 000] people in the district. The vaccines cost anywhere between Rs. 1500-2200 [USD 23-33] in the market, but we are providing it free of cost," he explained.

Dr. Mrigha further stated that the department would send each house a vaccination card with information including the date and place of vaccination. People will have to carry the card along with them to the venue.

[The above report does not indicate how many of the 20 deaths and 100 registered encephalitis cases are due to Japanese encephalitis (JE) virus infection or how many are classified as non-JE acute encephalitis.

JE virus is endemic in northeastern India, including West Bengal. As mentioned in many previous comments, the encephalitis picture in northeastern India is complicated. The JE virus etiology of some previously reported encephalitis cases has been confirmed by laboratory tests. However, many cases go undiagnosed, or JE virus infection is ruled out, and other etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease and lychee consumption, have been proposed. Vaccination is likely to be more effective for prevention of JE cases than vector control. Ardeid birds (heron family) are reservoir hosts.

From: T. Jacob John <tjacobjohn@yahoo.co.in> [edited]


The media report cited in the posting [Japanese encephalitis & other - India (16): (BR) 20151116.3794161] describes cases diagnosed as acute encephalitis syndrome (AES). Of 123 AES cases, only 35 were laboratory confirmed as Japanese encephalitis (JE). Of 23 deaths, 8 had JE, and 15 had other diseases. I quote from the report: "Health officials claim to have undertaken [a] massive immunization drive in the district to prevent [spread of] the deadly disease. But the claims have fallen flat after the outbreak of the disease, which took almost epidemic form."

Churchill's statement on the war situation fits the AES situation perfectly: "It is a riddle wrapped in mystery inside an enigma, but perhaps there is a key." I know that immunization against JE had been on a very large scale. Disturbingly, several JE-vaccinated children have had laboratory confirmed JE. Some among them have died. The outbreak, in spite of widespread immunization, does not disprove the claim of immunization, as there are genuine vaccine failure cases. However, in the absence of public health surveillance, quantified and validated data are not available. Moreover, the great majority of AES cases were not JE.

Two very relevant questions have been raised in the most recent issue of Lancet Infectious Diseases. One (DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/S1473-3099(15)00402-8) is that counterfeit drugs and vaccines are prevalent; I hope that the national immunization programme has adequate quality checks, but it is quite possible that spurious vaccine could enter the supply chain. This needs careful study and supervision. A colleague from Nepal tells me that vaccine failure is virtually zero there.

The 2nd (DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/S1473-3099(15)00405-3) is that all so-called laboratory-proven JE may not be JE at all. The positive predictive value of some of the currently recommended confirmatory tests, particularly detection of anti-IgM antibody, even in cerebrospinal fluid, may be false positive, as many cases have other infections with bacteria, fungi, or viruses.

There is a key to the riddle: where JE is prevalent, health management must be modernized with quality assurance of medical care, reliable laboratory support service, public health surveillance, and problem-solving research in medical colleges. The very tendency to club any and all brain disease as AES, even in medical colleges, illustrates the need for professionalism in public health and medical care.

--
T. Jacob John
Retired Professor of Clinical Virology,
Christian Medical College,
Vellore, India
<tjacobjohn@yahoo.co.in>

[ProMED thanks Dr. John for his comments.

Dr. John has again called for an integrated approach for surveillance with adequate laboratory support and dissemination of information that emerges to clinicians and to public health authorities as guidance for patient treatment and JE vaccination efforts. He also reiterates the need for more specific diagnosis of the etiology or etiologies of AES, since JE virus infections have been excluded in many cases, as noted in his comments and previous ProMED-mail posts. Those previous ProMED-mail posts have implicated Reye syndrome, consumption of lychees, and heat stroke, as well as JE virus infections, as responsible for AES. Prevention and control of AES will be difficult until there is a clear indication of the etiologies involved in these cases.

With 1 more death reported from Anugrah Narain Magadh Medical College Hospital, the number of encephalitis deaths has gone up to 24. Altogether, 123 AES [acute encephalitis syndrome] patients were admitted to the children's ward of the ANMMCH with AES symptoms. Of these, 35 of the patients were found suffering from Japanese encephalitis, the more deadly form of the disease.

Confirming 24 deaths due to AES this season, ANMMCH superintendent Dr SK Sinha said that 35 of the 123 AES patients admitted to the hospital this season tested JE positive. Giving a further breakdown, the superintendent said that of the 23 deaths reported this season, 8 suffered from Japanese encephalitis while the other 15 died due to AES.

Now that the temperature has come down and winter is beginning to set in, there was little likelihood of the disease spreading any further. Altogether 96 encephalitis patients have been discharged while another 4 were undergoing treatment in the children's ward of the hospital; 2 of the patients were discharged on Friday [13 Nov 2015] after satisfactory recovery.

The encephalitis survivors have suffered mild to severe mental retardation and physical infirmities, particularly weakening of the upper and lower limbs. Facilities for the rehabilitation of the AES survivors are not available in the hospital and as such the discharged patients have to fend for themselves. According to activist Brajnandan Pathak, the affected patients -- being very poor (almost all of them belong to the Mahadalit social group) -- cannot afford rehabilitation at centres outside the district.

As per available statistics, the maximum number of AES deaths were reported in 2011 when no fewer than 70 children died of encephalitis in ANMMCH alone. In 2009 too, 46 AES deaths took place. The numbers of affected children in 2011 and 2009 were 321 and 151 respectively.

Health officials claim to have undertaken a massive immunisation drive in the district to prevent [spread of] the deadly disease. But the claims have fallen flat after the outbreak of the disease which took almost epidemic form.

[Byline: Abdul Qadir]

Prevention and control of AES will be difficult until there is a clear indication of the etiologies involved in these cases. - Mod.TY

Notwithstanding claims of mass immunisation for acute encephalitis syndrome [AES] including the more deadly Japanese encephalitis [JE], at least 6 deaths have been reported. Another 21 patients suffering from the deadly disease are undergoing treatment in the children ward of the Anugrah Narain Magadh Medical College and Hospital [ANMMCH, in Gaya, Bihar].

With encephalitis cases reported from Fatehpur, Atri, and Manpur areas of the district [Gaya], the deadly disease threatens to take an epidemic form. Almost all the victims belong to the marginalised sections of the society. More deaths cannot be ruled out, as being poor, a sizeable number of affected people die at the hands of the quacks and faith healers.

Confirming 6 deaths, civil surgeon Dr Krishna Mohan Purvey said that 3 of the victims hail from Gaya district while the other 3 are from neighbouring areas including Aurangabad. The civil surgeon claimed that preventive steps have been taken in the affected areas through fogging and awareness creation. Surveillance has been stepped up and Asha workers have been galvanised to maintain surveillance and counsel affected families.

Giving break up of the encephalitis patients undergoing treatment in the ANMMCH, the civil surgeon said that of the 21 cases testing positive [for what? - Mod.TY], 2 cases have been confirmed as those of Japanese encephalitis [virus infections].

The remaining 19 are cases of acute encephalitis syndrome. Symptoms for both AES and Japanese encephalitis are more or less the same and as such, clinical diagnosis was not possible. The cases are confirmed only after proper [laboratory] test. The civil surgeon claimed that test kits were available in adequate numbers.

RTI [Right to Information Act] activist Brajnandan Pathak has demanded development of specialised infrastructure for encephalitis management and rehabilitation. Even the survivors, in many cases suffer permanent physical disability and mental retardation necessitating rehabilitation.

Encephalitis, it may be recalled, has been hitting the area with annual frequency and as such, a comprehensive solution is required. Visits of central and state level teams have become ritualistic and the more than a decade long menace has not been effectively contained.

[Byline: Abdul Qadir]

ProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts
<promed@promedmail.org>

[Encephalitis cases occur annually in India's northeastern states, including Bihar. Although Bihar is endemic for JE virus, not all encephalitis cases are due to infection by this virus as has been noted repeatedly in ProMED-mail comments.

The mass vaccinations mentioned in the report above will be effective against Japanese encephalitis virus infections, but they will not be effective for other causes of acute encephalitis syndrome because the etiologies of these cases has not been established. Other etiologies have been proposed (see ProMED-mail archive no 20150909.3633134). Until the etiologies of the non-JE cases is determined, these cases will continue to occur each year.

Maps of India can be seen at http://www.mapsofindia.com/images2/india-map.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12255. A map showing the location of Gaya in Bihar state can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/bihar/. - Mod.TY]

Another child suspected to be suffering from Japanese encephalitis (JE) died in Lucknow on Friday night [11 Sep 2015], bringing the toll to over 50 from Pilibhit district.

All these patients were suspected to be suffering from JE, say medical sources here. According to sources, a critically ill girl, aged 6 from Udaipur village in Amariya, was referred to Lucknow by district hospital doctors on 21 Aug [2015] because she was suspected to be suffering from JE. She received treatment in Lucknow for more than 2 weeks but could not be saved.

Numerous children suspected to be suffering from JE across Bareilly division are reported to have died over the past 2 months, but there are no facilities to either diagnose or treat the disease in Bareilly and its neighbouring districts.

All suspected patients of JE are referred to Lucknow, which is far away [270 km (170 miles)], and precious time is wasted in taking patients to the city. Delay in treatment can prove fatal, say doctors here.

Dr Om Chauhan, chief medical officer, told TOI: "The increasing number of suspected JE deaths is a real worry for us at the moment. We have organized camps in rural areas where more numbers of cases are reported. We have also alerted all hospitals in the district to report all the suspected cases with their medical history. Dr Prashant, district malaria officer, is coordinating in case of all such cases."

According to the World Health Organization (WHO), around 500-600 people die every year in UP because of JE. However, the actual mortality rate in Bareilly division is yet to be confirmed, as no diagnostic lab is available in these districts.

More than 50 people, mostly children, have died over the past 2 months in Pilibhit district. However, no official death is yet registered because all the suspected patients died in private hospitals or outside the district, said medical sources.

[Byline: Kanwardeep Singh]

<promed@promedmail.org>

[It is curious that no mention is made in the above report of whether there has been a recent vaccination campaign in this district against JE virus, nor specifically whether any of the 50 fatal cases had been vaccinated.

Although Uttar Preddsh is endemic for JE virus, not all encephalitis cases are due to infection by this virus. Other etiologies have been proposed (see ProMED-mail archive no. 20150909.3633134). It is unfortunate that the nearest diagnostic laboratory is so far away from the district. Until there are reliable diagnostic laboratory services close at hand, and until the etiology of the non-JE cases is determined, these cases will continue to occur each year.

[1] Nepal
Date: Fri 11 Sep 2015
Source: Kathmandu Post [edited]
http://kathmandupost.ekantipur.com/news/2015-09-11/japanese-encephalitis-claims-life.html


A boy at Bankatti in Bhimdatta Municipality-14 [Kanchanpur district, Far-Western region, Nepal] has died of Japanese encephalitis in the district.

The deceased has been identified as a 6-year-old boy of Saraswoti Tole. He breathed his last while being treated at Baraily in India [Uttar Pradesh state] 2 weeks ago. Meanwhile, another local resident, 55 [years old], is said to be suffering from the same disease and is undergoing treatment at in Baraily.

Dr Suvesh Raj Kayastha of Seti Zonal Hospital said the disease was confirmed based on symptoms. Though immunisation against the disease was carried out in the area, health authorities said even those who were vaccinated against the ailment may suffer from the disease in some cases.

According to health workers, the disease is transmitted from infected animals including pigs, wild boars and ducks to humans by mosquitoes belonging to _Culex_ species. And, while one can be vaccinated for the disease, there is no specific medication for the treatment. Hence, the treatment is focused on relieving severe clinical signs and supporting patients to overcome the infection.

[Byline: Bhahwani Bhatta]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED-mail
<promed@promedmail.org>

[The lowland tropical areas of Nepal are endemic for Japanese encephalitis. However, diagnosis of Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) infection based on clinical grounds alone without laboratory tests to support it is uncertain, given that a number of viruses can cause encephalitis. The vaccination status of the 2 cases is not given, although JEV immunizations were carried out in the area. If the inactivated virus vaccine was used, the duration of immunity would not have been long lasting.

Pigs are mentioned in the above report because they can serve as amplifying hosts for JEV. Birds, especially ardeids (herons), are reservoir hosts, and the mosquito vectors are several _Culex_ species.

Bhimdatta is the 9th largest city in Nepal. It is 5 kilometres (about 3.1 miles) east of the Indian border and 700 kilometres (about 430 miles) west of Kathmandu. It is in the tropical zone of Nepal, where the habitat favors transmission of JEV.

A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Nepal can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/18608. - Mod.TY]

******
[2] India (Uttar Pradesh)
Date: Thu 10 Sep 2015
Source: The Times of India [edited]
http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/varanasi/Encephalitis-claims-4-lives-toll-161-in-Gorakhpur/articleshow/48896784.cms


Encephalitis claimed 4 more lives here [Gorakhpur, Uttar Pradesh state, India] since Tuesday [8 Sep 2015], increasing the death toll to 161 this year. Local MP Yogi Adityanath visited the BRD Medical College where most of the encephalitis patients are admitted, and met the grieved family.

On Wednesday [9 Sep 2015], 4 individuals died of encephalitis, while 14 encephalitis patients were admitted to the medical college since Tuesday. A total of 828 encephalitis cases have been reported till date in the medical college among which 125 are still undergoing treatment.

Yogi Adityanath [member of parliament] visited the medical college and consoled the aggrieved families. He also inspected the encephalitis and academic wards and asked the attendants about the facilities available. He also inquired about the ventilators in the hospital.

While talking to reporters, he said that he would discuss the problems of the hospital, including shortage of staff, with the state's health minister.

On the death of children, chief campaigner of Encephalitis Eradication Movement, Dr R N Singh said, "Hundreds of children are dying year after year due to encephalitis. This disease is 100 percent preventable but the government always puts stress on development of ways of cure rather than its prevention. We could eradicate encephalitis totally from the country if we invest resources on timely execution of prevention activities."

--
Communicated by:
ProMED-mail
<promed@promedmail.org>

[There have been numerous JE cases in northeastern India again in 2015. Since this area is in the JE virus endemic area, with human cases occurring every year, these additional cases are not surprising.

Eradication of the disease would only be possible if the etiologies of the encephalitis cases were known. Some, but not all cases are due to JEV infections and could be prevented by vaccination. Other etiologies could be involved and include enterovirus infection from contaminated water, Reye syndrome, lychee consumption and heatstroke (see ProMED-mail archive no. 20150909.3633134). - Mod.TY

Date: Sun 6 Sep 2015
Source: Web India123 [edited]
http://news.webindia123.com/news/Articles/India/20150906/2674750.html


The death toll in the recent spate of encephalitis [in Gorakhpur district, Uttar Pradesh] rose to 147 when 3 more children died of the dreaded disease during the past 24 hours.

An official said all the deaths are reported from BRD Medical College in Gorakhpur. "Of the 3 fresh deaths -- one each from Basti and Gorakhpur, one from adjoining Bihar state," official sources said. All the dead were children in the age group of 5-15 years, the official in Gorakhpur said.

Baba Raghav Das Medical College Superintendent NN Shukla said, "Since January [2015], 693 children suffering from encephalitis were admitted to the Baba Raghav Das Medical College [in Gorakhpur], of which 147 died." Patients admitted to the hospital who were suffering from encephalitis belonged to the districts of Gorakhpur, Deoria, Gonda, Basti, Sidharthnagar, Sankabrinagar, Kushinagar, Balrampur, Ghazipur, Azamgarh, while some patients came from Nepal and Bihar.

The area is endemic for Japanese encephalitis but in the past 6 years, children have been dying of other forms of viral encephalitis, the exact cause of which is unclear. One possibility is that the water-borne virus was present in contaminated water, doctors said.

The diseases cause headache and vomiting and can lead to coma, brain dysfunction, seizures, and inflammations of the heart and kidney.

Doctors say children between the age of 6 months-15 years are the worst affected and most of the victims are poor people from rural areas.

With this disease taking epidemic propositions every year, Convener of the National Encephalitis Eradication Program (NEEP) RN Singh has written a letter to Prime Minister Narendra Modi, requesting him to declare encephalitis eradication programme as national programme. "The need of the hour is to make encephalitis eradication programme a national programme.

The issue has been raised more than 20 times in the Lok Sabha by MP from Gorakhpur Yogi Aditanath. "A National Programme for Prevention and Control of Encephalitis was made twice -- first in 2011 and then in 2014. But it is very unfortunate that it is yet to come out of the drawing board," he wrote in his letter, which was released to the media today. He said, "The disease is 100 per cent preventable but does not have any specific treatment. Till now, government's major stress has been on the treatment only, but what is important is that the government should look after the prevention part too."

"Many countries where it was a major problem have almost eradicated it. Some decades back, countries like China, Japan, and Korea were ravaged by encephalitis. Now these countries are encephalitis-free. If these countries can do it, so can we," he said. The disease is predictable and preventable. The annual monsoon fills parched paddy fields, which bear the mosquitoes that spread Japanese encephalitis from pigs to humans, devastating malnourished children with low immunity.

Another strain of the disease acute encephalitis syndrome spreads through contaminated water. Residents defecate in the fields, contaminating the ground water.

A vaccine has long been available, but the disease killed more than 1500 children in 2005 and 431 in 2006. In 2006, a vaccination drive was launched. The government vowed to immunise every child in the worst-affected areas and to launch a massive drive to improve sanitation. For a couple of years, the numbers dropped also.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED-mail
<promed@promedmail.org>

[Outbreaks of encephalitis occur regularly in north eastern India, where these cases occurred. Before an effective prevention program can be launched, it is necessary to know the etiologies responsible for these cases. Japanese encephalitis virus is responsible for some, but not all cases. Many reports associate contaminated water, presumably carrying enteroviruses, with these outbreaks.

Dr Jacob John has asserted that many of these are hypoglycemic Reye syndrome cases. He noted that in the pre-monsoon period, particularly in May and June, outbreaks of Reye-like acute hypoglycemic encephalopathy occur in the northwestern region of Bihar state and that is also popularly, but unfortunately, called AES (acute encephalitis syndrome). Many doctors, the media, and the public consider these encephalopathy cases as encephalitis because of the term AES. This has been now clarified and in June 2014 children were treated by 10 per cent dextrose infusion and many lives were saved (under publication). A published article in a pediatric journal proposed that some cases are due to heat stroke. It has been proposed that consumption of lychees is responsible for some encephalitis cases. Encephalopathy and hypoglycemia have been associated with consumption of lychee fruit containing phytotoxins, specifically alpha-(methylenecyclopropyl)glycine. Until the etiological agents responsible for the cases are definitively identified, these unfortunate cases will continue.

Maps of India can be seen at http://www.mapsofindia.com/images2/india-map.jpg
and of Gorakhpur, Uttar Pradesh at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1307. - Mod.TY]

Meghalaya has sounded an alert for Japanese encephalitis [JE] after 3 people died of the disease and another 6 were tested positive for the virus, an official said on Tuesday [18 Aug 2015].

"We have sounded a health alert in the state after 3 people died of Japanese encephalitis and 6 people were tested for the virus," Director of Health Services R. Wankhar said.

State Health and Family Welfare Minister Alexander Hek, after a meeting with medical officials, said the government has taken steps to contain the spread of the virus. Health officials will also undertake fogging in various localities to tackle _Culex_ mosquitoes, which are responsible for the outbreak of Japanese encephalitis, and their breeding grounds.

"We have directed the hospital authorities to provide adequate treatment and medicines to those suffering from the disease," Hek said.

Encephalitis results in inflammation of the brain, affecting the patient's central nervous system. It is caused by bacterial or viral infections of the brain, injection of toxic substances, or increased complications of an infectious disease.

While the lesser symptoms include headache and fever, the more severe ones cause seizures, confusion, disorientation, tremors, and hallucinations. Japanese encephalitis syndrome is [caused by] a mosquito-borne virus. While humans are the dead-end hosts of the virus, pigs act as amplifying hosts that aid in spread of the virus.

Since this area is in the JE virus endemic area, with human cases occurring every year, these additional cases are not surprising.

In Meghalaya's South West Garo Hills district, 3 people died of Japanese encephalitis (JE), prompting the district administration to reach out to citizens to prevent the disease from assuming epidemic proportions.

Japanese encephalitis claimed 3 lives in and around Ampati, the headquarters of South West Garo Hills, an official communique stated. Another case has been reported in the district.

Deputy commissioner Ram Singh today called a meeting with district officials, nokmas (headmen), NGOs, local leaders and senior citizens to take stock of the situation. The veterinary officer has been directed to test pigs and check pigsties.

In a rare case of Japanese encephalitis (JE), a mosquito-borne disease, a 4-year-old boy from Keezhlsathamangalur near Ariyur here died at the Institute of Child Health in Chennai on 1 Aug [2015].

Initially, the boy was administered rabies vaccine at Indira Gandhi Government General Hospital and Post Graduate Institute (IGMCRI) after being bitten by a stray dog, but subsequently the family took him to the JIPMER [Jawaharlal Institute of Postgraduate Medical Education & Research].

When the boy developed fever and complications, suspecting it to be a case of rabies encephalopathy, JIPMER referred the boy to Rajiv Gandhi Women and Children Hospital on 27 Jul 2015. The parents instead took the child to IGMCRI, which in turn referred the boy to Chennai.

This is a rare (JE) case reported in Puducherry, though in some parts of neighbouring Villupuram district it is endemic, Director of Health and Family Welfare Dr K V Raman told Express. The departments of Revenue, Local Administration and Vector Control Research centre (VCRC) were alerted. The entire region was surveyed for fever cases. Blood test was done for more than 90 residents. Fogging was done to destroy all mosquitoes. Ducks and cranes were removed and tested. Stagnant water in the fields was drained out by the Agriculture Department.

Meanwhile, the Sentinel Surveillance unit for JE is being set up after getting approval from National Rural Health Mission (NRHM), said Dr Raman. Diagnostic kits are being procured from National institute of Virology, Pune. Till the testing facilities are established, samples will be sent to District Hospitals in Villupuram and Cuddalore, he added.

[Byline: Debjani Dutta]

At least 66 people people have died of Japanese encephalitis this year across Assam, chief minister Tarun Gogoi on Monday [27 Jul 2015] said.

"So far, 66 deaths have been reported from various districts in Assam. Though the severity is lesser this year than the previous years, we are taking it very seriously," Gogoi told reporters here.

The government has taken all precautionary measures like vaccination, distribution of mosquito nets, insecticides among others to stop further spread of the disease, he said.

[This is the Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) transmission season in northeastern India, and the number of fatal cases in Assam state has increased from 22 on 21 Jul 2015 (see ProMED-mail archive no. 20150722.3529096) to 66 just a week later. It is not clear from the above report if the 66 cases cited above are all laboratory confirmed as JEV infections. The numbers of reported JE cases in Assam have been increasing over several years. Between 2010 and 2014, the number of annual cases rose from 154 to 744, with deaths rising from 41-160, according to data from the Assam health department. The disease, which in 2009 was recorded in only half of the state's districts, now is seen in all of them. Doctors say climate change has played a major role in the spread of the disease, which once appeared largely from May to July but now is seen as late in the year as November, as mosquitoes survive longer in warmer conditions (see ProMED-mail archive no. 20150128.3126931).

Although mention is made of an Assam-wide vaccination, the vaccination status of the 66 fatal cases is not given in the above report nor is the JE virus vaccination status of the population in the affected area. The virus doubtless is endemic in northeastern India. Ardeid birds (heron family) are reservoir hosts.

[1] Vaccinated Japanese encephalitis cases
Date: Thu 16 Jul 2015
Source: The Times of India [edited]
http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Japanese-encephalitis-jitters-5-vaccinated-cases-test-positive/articleshow/48093204.cms


The state [Assam] health department, which has a Japanese encephalitis (JE) vaccination programme, suffered a major embarrassment after 5 of the 175 JE-positive cases in the state were found to have been previously vaccinated.

As the state continued to reel from JE, district health officials said vaccination cannot provide foolproof protection, as a lot of factors like immunity, nutrition level, body mechanism and surroundings, dictate the performance of the vaccines.

All the 5 affected persons were within the age bracket that is considered to be eligible for the SA 14-14-2 vaccine. The vaccine is administered to people between 1-65 years of age.

The 5 cases were reported from Dhemaji, Dibrugarh, Golaghat and Tinsukia districts. Tinsukia reported 2 cases: a 9-year-old girl from the tea garden community and a 54-year-old man.

In March [2015], the state government launched the vaccination programme for kids in 11 districts and that for adults in 3 districts. Tinsukia district joint director of health Jyoti Bhuyan said the 9-year-old girl from the tea garden community was vaccinated earlier as part of the district's routine immunization programme, but her surroundings were unhygienic, and she was not properly nourished.

"Even after being vaccinated, there are chances that a person might fall ill. When we investigated the girl's case, we found that there were pigs in the area where she was staying," said Bhuyan.

Tinsukia district reported 7 cases of JE. No casualty has been reported so far. The 54-year-old man was administered the vaccine during the 1st phase of the adult vaccination programme last year [2014].

"The immunity cannot be 100 percent. There remains a chance of infection. Vaccination performance depends on the body mechanism of the recipient along with one's standard of living and exposure to the environment," said Aboni Borthakur, joint director health, Golaghat.

Meanwhile, the virus has claimed 4 lives in Hailakandi district. All of them died at Silchar Medical College Hospital (SMCH) in the past one week, said a senior officer of the district malaria department in Hailakandi on [Wed 15 Jul 2015]. He said 7 more are battling for their lives.

District programme manager of the malaria department Ujjwal Barbhuiyan said the department distributed medicated [insecticide impregnated bed] nets in the district.

[Byline: Gaurav Das]

[2] Vaccine-resistant strain suspected
Date: Mon 20 Jul 2015
Source: The Times of India [edited]
http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/guwahati/State-health-officials-fear-vaccine-resistant-strain-of-JE/articleshow/48136653.cms


State [Assam] health officials fear that a possible new vaccine-resistant strain of Japanese encephalitis (JE) virus, which may have gained virulence, could be the cause of the outbreak of the vector-borne disease in areas covered by vaccination drives.

The highest number of JE positive cases this year [2015] has been reported from Sivasagar district, which was the 1st district in the state where the adult vaccination campaign was launched in 2012.

Sivasagar district joint director of health services Ripun Borpujari said: "This could be a new JE strain, and the virus may have developed resistance to the vaccine. We have intensified awareness and fogging programmes in an effort to combat the JE scourge."

He added that the health department also planned to conduct a survey to study the fever cases. "We are planning a door-to-door survey to study the fever cases. The positive JE cases are fewer compared to last year [2014]. It could be that this is the new JE strain that we are encountering, and it is possible that the virus has gained more virulence," said Borpujari.

More than 200 JE positive cases are being treated at different hospitals across the state. Till [Sat 18 Jul 2015], 38 persons have died, with the highest number of deaths reported from Sivasagar district.

In 2014, Sivasagar district had reported 128 positive cases, and, with the peak season for JE set to continue for 2 more months, Sivasagar district remains vulnerable. This year [2015] so far, 24 confirmed cases have been reported from the district. 14 acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) cases have also been reported.

Experts also fear that with its sprawling paddy fields and large pig population in the oil-rich Sivasagar district, there could be further positive and confirmed JE cases across the district.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED-SoAs
<promed-SoAs@promedmail.org>

[According to the 1st news report, Japanese encephalitis (JE) developed among 5 people who were vaccinated with SA 14-14-2 vaccine. Among them, a 9-year-old girl was malnourished and had exposure to pigs at her home. The local health officials have stated that the vaccine does not confer 100 percent immunity and that various environmental and host factors, including nutritional status, affect the level of immune response following vaccination. Of note, SA 14-14-2 vaccine is a live-attenuated vaccine using the SA 14-14-2 JE virus strain. Vaccine efficacy following a single-dose of vaccine has been reported to vary between 80 to 99.3 percent from different studies (http://www.path.org/publications/files/SA14142-fact-sheet-1013.pdf). The vaccine has been shown to confer immunity for up to 5 years with 96.2 percent efficacy.

According to the 2nd news report, 38 JE deaths have been reported from the state of Assam as of 18 Jul 2015. The state health officials suspect that a new vaccine-resistant strain of JE virus has become virulent and is causing outbreaks among the vaccinated people in the state. However, it is not clear whether the suspicion is based on virus isolation and sequencing from cases. Since the vaccine does not confer 100 percent immunity, the residents in the affected areas need to be advised to take personal protective measures against mosquito bites.

For the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Assam state, India, see http://healthmap.org/promed/p/299. - Mod.SN]

[If the vaccine provides 96 per cent immunity, then one might expect vaccine failure in 6 of the 175 JE cases mentioned in the 1st report. There were 5 vaccine failures. Proof of "vaccine-resistant" JE virus or a gain in virulence requires further information and study to answer several critical questions. Has there been a demonstrable change in antigenicity in the field (wild) strains of JE virus that are in circulation? Do the vaccinated individuals have JE virus antibody, and if so, does that antibody neutralize current JE virus field isolates as well as it does the vaccine strain of the virus, indicating a change in antigenicity? Is a greater proportion of JE virus-infected individuals developing neurological disease than is typical for JE virus infections indicating an increase in neurovirulence? Changes in virulence would have to be determined in animal studies comparing current fields strains of the virus with standard or reference virus strains. Apparently, not all cases of encephalitis in Assam (and other areas in northeast India) are due to JE virus infections, further complicating the situation. Other etiologies have been suggested as a cause of non-JE virus acute encephalitis syndrome (see ProMED-mail archive nos. 20150225.3183897 and 20140801.2652476), for which JE vaccines would provide no protection. - Mod.TY]

The Joint Director said they have so far distributed 33 000 [insectice-treated] mosquito nets in the affected areas and in JE-prone areas and organised 205 health awareness camps.

The situation was being closely monitored and blood samples collected to ascertain whether there were more cases of JE in the district.

Spraying of DDT and fogging have been initiated in over 45 villages in and around the Jorhat district.

A child suffering from Japanese encephalitis died today [14 Jul 2015] at the North Bengal Medical College and Hospital [NBMCH], taking the death toll from the dreaded disease to 24 in North Bengal since January [2015].

The boy, under treatment at the hospital in Siliguri for the past several days, died at the hospital, NBMCH acting Superintendent Nirmal Bera said.

He said 14 persons have died of the mosquito-borne disease since 1 Jul [2015] at the hospital. A total of 24 have died since the outbreak of the disease in the 1st week of January 2015, Bera added.

17 persons were currently undergoing treatment, he said, adding that patients were from Jalpaiguri and Darjeeling Hill district areas of the region. Of the 17 afflicted with the disease, 4 were in the paediatrics department.

Meanwhile, Siliguri Mayor Ashok Bhattacharya went around the wards of the hospital and talked to the patients' families. Bhattacharya said that to avert any outbreak of the disease in Siliguri, camps were being set up for collecting blood samples, and people are being asked to dispose of stagnant water and maintain close vigil on cow sheds.

So far, no case has been reported from the Siliguri city area, he added.

http://www.avenuemail.in/jamshedpur/fresh-cases-of-japanese-encephalitis-being-reported-every-day/73290/


Concerned over increasing cases of vector borne diseases and some cases of dengue surfacing in the district [East Singhbhum district, Jharkhand state], the health department has sounded an alert.

In the city [Jamshedpur], 5 suspect cases have been reported. East Singhbhum IDSP officer Sahir Pall said that all 5 suspected cases' samples have been sent for confirmatory test at vector lab MGM Medical College of Dimna in Mango.

The 3 suspected cases' blood samples from Tata Main Hospital (TMH) are of a 5-year-old, an 11-year-old who is a resident of Chakradharpur and a 60-year-old, while 2 samples sent from Baridih-based Mercy Hospital are of 4-and-a-half-year-old and another individual.

The East Singhbhum district health department has decided to embark on the outdoor awareness campaigns. As part of the campaign, huge hording educating the people will be placed at strategic locations in the city.

Considering the high number of Japanese encephalitis (JE) cases detected in the city so far, the department has also decided to take out hordings specifically for JE. JE is a vector borne viral disease transmitted by mosquitoes after feeding on infected animals such as pigs and wild birds in the agriculture fields.

The department, which earlier used to only spray larvicidal, apart from undertaking cleanliness exercise will be opting for destroying unused containers (identified vector breeding centers) in the affected areas and educating people on not allowing water to stagnate in residential areas. This exercise would be held simultaneously with routine methods of spraying larvicidal in the area.

From district health department records, in the year 2010, over 10 000 viral cases were reported in the district in the monsoon period. The figure rose to 16 000 in 2011, mostly from chikungunya and dengue. In 2012 there were around 8000 viral cases in the city.

The local residents said that though the district health department took initiative to curb the menace, again the diseases have shot up, making life difficult for the people.

Manoj Hansda, a social worker, said that the administration lacks will to work in the fringe areas due to [the fact that] the situation is far from safe.

"I think immediate steps need to be taken to control the menace. The health department needs to spread awareness in the villages and necessary medicines should be distributed," he noted.

[Jharkhand state is located in northeastern India, an area where numerous cases of encephalitis, some due to Japanese encephalitis (JE) virus, are reported annually, usually beginning at this time of year. The above report indicates that several mosquito-borne viruses appear to be transmitted in that locality currently. As mentioned in previous comments, the encephalitis picture in northeastern India is complicated. The JE virus etiology of some previously reported encephalitis cases has been confirmed by laboratory tests. However, many cases go undiagnosed or JE virus infection is ruled out, and other etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, have been proposed. No mention is made of JE virus vaccination status of the above cases nor of the population in the affected area. Vaccination is more likely to be more effective for prevention of JE cases than vector control, particularly in the areas of paddy rice cultivation that provide abundant _Culex_ vector mosquito breeding sites. The virus doubtless is endemic in northeastern India. Ardeid birds (heron family) are reservoir hosts.

Source: Reuters [edited]
http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/01/26/us-india-encephalitis-idUSKBN0KZ10L20150126


Cases of deadly mosquito-borne Japanese encephalitis [JE] have risen nearly 5-fold in 5 years in India's northeast Assam state as a result of warming weather and changing rainfall, health experts say.

Between 2010 and 2014, the number of annual cases rose from 154 to 744, with deaths rising from 41-160, according to data from the Assam health department. The disease, which in 2009 was recorded in only half of the state's districts, now is seen in all of them.

Doctors say climate change has played a major role in the spread of the disease, which once appeared largely from May to July but now is seen as late in the year as November, as mosquitoes survive longer in warmer conditions.

Japanese encephalitis is characterized by inflammation of the brain and high fever.

"Now, the temperature ... which is ideal for breeding of the _Culex_ mosquito, is present almost until October or so, and as a result of this, the cases of the disease are increasing," said Rabindra Nath Talukdar, a senior official of the Assam health department.

"Initially, it was only an upper Assam disease ... but now it has also been detected in lower Assam districts, and (now) cases have been reported from all the 27 districts in Assam," Talukdar said.

Health department officials said changes in agricultural patterns may be affecting the rise in encephalitis cases. Warmer conditions have allowed farmers to grow more crops of rice each year, which means rice paddies with standing water offer a breeding ground for mosquitoes for a larger part of each year. "The _Culex_ mosquito breeds on water in the agricultural land, and now since there is water on the field for several more months than before, it gives more time and space for the mosquito to breed," Talukdar said.

Faced with a surge in Japanese encephalitis cases, the Assam government has announced measures to tackle the problem, including more careful monitoring of cases. Assam Health Minister Nazrul Islam described the situation as "a huge concern. I have asked the senior officials of the health department to monitor the situation carefully and to report to me on a regular basis," he said.

Faced with a growing public outcry over the disease's rapid spread, Assam Chief Minister Tarun Gogoi has ordered officials of the Assam health department to develop a plan to control the disease.

Plans should include "setting up of an intensive care unit in each district hospital for treatment of emergency cases, along with laboratory testing units," Gogoi said. As well, "I have already asked the health department to procure laboratory testing kits for quick diagnosis of the disease, adequate vaccines and medicines for the hospitals, and also to carry out intensive fogging in the affected areas," he said.

Civil society groups and activists have, however, questioned why such steps were not taken earlier. "The data from the state health department itself shows that the disease has taken a deadly turn over the years in the state. Unfortunately, the state machinery waited for the disease to go out of control, whereas it should have taken steps to control the disease much earlier," said Sankar Prasad Rai, of the All Assam Students Union (AASU).

Several influential student groups of the state, including the All Assam Students Union and the Assam Jatiyatibadi Yuva Chatra Parishad (AJYCP), have staged protests over the government's failure to control the spread of Japanese encephalitis.

[Byline: Amarjyoti Borah]

The above report indicates that the cases referred to in Assam are JE. Increased surveillance, coupled with timely laboratory support, is very important for any control efforts to be successful. Although delivery of JE virus vaccine to hospitals is mentioned, it is curious that no mention is made of an Assam-wide vaccination campaign, nor is there mention of campaigns in previous years. Vaccination is more likely to be more effective for prevention of JE cases than vector control, particularly with the increase in the areas of paddy rice cultivation that provide _Culex_ vector mosquito breeding sites. Source: Odisha Sun Times [edited]
http://odishasuntimes.com


A mystery disease continues to create mayhem in backward Malkangiri district of Odisha. While 11 children have already fallen victim to it as per the report of the Chief District Medical officer (CDMO), unofficial sources, however, have put the toll at 20. The disease continues to spread at an alarming rate in Korkonda, Kalimela and Padia blocks.

"The disease is seen among children aged between one and 15. It starts with fever and causes vomiting, joint pain and muscle aches. The patients usually die within a day or 2," said Ghenu Madhi from Patrel village.

Health Department Odisha specialist medical teams from Bhubaneswar, Cuttack and Berhampur have now reached the affected villages, such as Materu, Patrel, Aerbanpalli, Rangamatiguda, Chimtapali, Buduri and Chintalwada to collect blood samples.

Speaking to Oisha Sun Times, Irma Kabasi of Aerbanpalli said: "The villagers are really scared and have sent the kids away to their relatives. The entire village is now deserted. There are only 33 doctors in different community health centres out of 97 granted positions. The villagers have no choice but to turn to the local priests and herbal doctors, which makes matters worse," added Bhakta Madhi of Rangamatiguda.

"Mobile medical teams have reached the spot and are treating the patients in the affected villages. Blood samples of infected children have also been sent to the laboratory, and the test report is awaited. However, from the primary symptoms, we suspect it to be Japanese encephalitis," said Uday Shankar Mishra, CDMO of Malkangiri.

[Byline: Rajan Rath]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts
<promed@promedmail.org>

[Because Japanese encephalitis is suspected from the primary symptoms noted (presumably encephalitis), ProMED requests information concerning the results of the laboratory tests on the blood of the children when they become available.

Previous reports from northeastern India have indicated that only a small proportion of encephalitis cases are due to infections with Japanese encephalitis virus. Others have associated some encephalitis cases with contaminated water. However, in revisiting the comments made by Dr T Jacob John, he mentioned that cases in this area early in the year may be due to a Reye-like syndrome. In a 24 Jun 2014 comment (ProMED-mail archive no 20140625.2563561) concerning the Reye-like syndrome, he stated that "the disease is undoubtedly hypoglycemic encephalopathy (with blood glucose levels below 40 in about half the children in whom testing was done), and lower than 80 in 80-85 percent. The lesson was to give 10 percent dextrose infusion as soon as possible after drawing blood for glucose measurement. Pediatricians who did this tell me that children given 10 percent dextrose within a short period of onset tend to recover within a few hours and are well to go home the next day."

In another comment on 3 Aug 2014 (see ProMED-mail archive no 20140804.2656983), he noted, "I understand that West Nile virus is also present in that region, and some AES [acute encephalitis syndrome] may indeed be West Nile encephalitis." He indicated that JEV cases occur later in the year during the typical JEV transmission season.

A 7 May 2014 report of a recent study from Odisha and Jharkhand states (ProMED-mail archive no 20140508.2459977) indicated that cases of acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) were caused by infections with viruses of dengue and measles. However, this study indicated that although herpes simplex virus (HSV) was a dominant agent for acute encephalitis, in some cases the viral agents were those of dengue and measles. Over 16 per cent of cases were found to be caused by viral agents identified to be either HSV I or II, while another 2.6 per cent of cases were due to measles virus infections. Similarly, Japanese encephalitis virus caused 1.5 per cent of cases, followed by 0.57 per cent by dengue virus. This still leaves nearly 80 per cent of the cases without a diagnosis.

The report above provides no information about the JEV vaccination status of the population in the affected areas or the specific dates of occurrence of these cases.

Maps of India can be seen at http://www.mapsofindia.com/images2/india-map.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/22405. - Mod.TY]

Source: The Hindustan Times [edited]

After Pune's National Institute of Virology (NIV) confirmed the presence of _Culex tritaeniorhynchus_ -- a mosquito which spreads Japanese encephalitis (JE) [virus], the Brihanmumbai [Greater Mumbai] Municipal Corporation [BMC] said it would study the report and then take preventive measures.

"This is the 1st reported case of JE in the city [Mumbai]. We are yet to receive the NIV report and only after we study it, we can decide further preventive actions," said Dr Mangala Gomare, chief of epidemiology cell, BMC.

After a 9-year-old Santacruz [Mumbai] girl tested positive for JE in September [2014], municipal health officials had claimed that the JE [virus]-spreading mosquito is not present in Mumbai.

According to National Vector Borne Disease Control Program (NVBDCP), this year [2014], 1316 cases and 242 deaths from JE [virus] infection were recorded in the country. Assam has reported the highest number of cases (756) and deaths (163) in the country, according to NVBDCP.

Doctors said the detection of the vector or carrier increases the possibility of transmission of the JE [virus] infection. "Though it is relatively uncommon infection, JE has a high morbidity and mortality.

Dr Neelu Desai, the paediatric neurologist who treated the Santacruz girl, said that she has been treating patients with JE symptoms. "It is just that we must have not tested all patients for the infection. The laboratory test is not vital in most cases as the patient only needs symptomatic treatment," she said.

Senior state health officials plan to ask BMC's insecticide department to regularly collect and test _Culex tritaeniorhynchus_ mosquito and larvae. "It is better we prevent the possibility of an outbreak," said an official.

[Byline: Priyanka Vora]

--

ProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts
<promed@promedmail.org>

[Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) is endemic in many parts of India, and cases occur there annually, especially in the north east part of the country. The case above is the 1st one that ProMED has posted for Maharashtra state this year (2014). There was an outbreak of encephalitis in Maharashtra state in 2011 and JEV was the suspected cause, but was not laboratory confirmed (see ProMED-mail archive no 20111106.3302). Presumably, the 1316 cases nationally reported above for this year (2014) were laboratory confirmed, and West Nile virus (WNV) cases were excluded. WNV, a close relative of JEV, also occurs in India. Without reliable laboratory diagnosis, the number of reported cases can be confusing, as many are reported in India as acute encephalitis syndrome cases and sometimes presumed to be due to JEV infections when, in fact, they are not.

It is not clear why the detection of _Culex tritaeniorhynchus_ in Mumbai, Maharashtra state is reported to be surprising. This mosquito species is widely distributed over south and south eastern Asia, including India (see http://www.mosquitocatalog.org/taxon_descr.aspx?ID=18465. Was its detection in Mumbai part of ongoing routine mosquito surveillance, or prompted in response to the case of Japanese encephalitis virus infection in the child?

A HealthMap/ProMED- mail showing the location of Mumbai can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/482. - Mod.TY]

The outbreak came after the disease killed over 130 children and affected over 700 of them in Muzaffarpur and its adjacent districts in north Bihar in May and June this year [2014].

Araria Civil Surgeon Dr BK Thakur said, "All deaths due to AES have been recorded in the district between 12 Aug-24 Sep [2014]. We have no information of any other child being affected by the disease after that."

All children who died due to AES are in the age group of 1-7 years and they belonged to families who live in the rural areas of Araria, and are not financially well-off.

The Civil Surgeon said intensive vaccination drive was being conducted in the affected areas of the districts and the disease seemed to be under control now.

AES has become an annual phenomenon during the pre-monsoon summer season in north Bihar districts. Scientists and researchers have so far been unable to identify the cause of the disease.

In absence of the identification of virus, bacteria, or any other agent that causes this deadly disease which has a death rate of 26 percent, doctors at their best could only provide symptomatic treatment to the patients.

Source: The Times of India [edited]
http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/varanasi/46-die-of-encephalitis-in-a-week/articleshow/41895273.cms


As many as 46 people have died of encephalitis in a week [approx. 1-7 Sep 2014], and 7 in the past 24 hours [6-7 Sep 2014]. BRD Medical College statistics reveal that 991 encephalitis cases have been reported since January this year [2014], among which 291 have died and 184 are undergoing treatment in the encephalitis ward of the medical college. The mortality rate this year is the highest in 3 years. At present, the rate is 29.4 per cent. In the year 2011, only 18 per cent of encephalitis patients died; in 2012, the mortality rate was 20.9 per cent; whereas in 2013, it was 29.3 per cent. The increase in the last 3 years raises question on the claims made by the government.

The government is not following Holiya village model formula where the mortality rate came to zero. The chief campaigner of Encephalitis Eradication Movement (EEM) said: "In order to eradicate encephalitis, we have been demanding implementation of 10-point programme of NEEP in the country but till 2009. To show effectiveness of programme, we adopted a village of Kushinagar district [Uttar Pradesh state] which was badly hit by encephalitis with 5 deaths and 4 handicapped encephalitis victims and no one vaccinated till 2009. From 1 Jan 2010, we adopted Holiya village and implemented 10-point programme of NEEP, with a resolution that we'll make the village encephalitis free by 31 Dec 2010."

"Every year, more than 500 people die of encephalitis, and I'm sure this year [2014] will not be an exception. The government is spending so much money on vaccination program of JE [Japanese encephalitis] which is only 4 per cent left and not focusing on prevention of enteroviral encephalitis," he said.

The Holiya village formula is based on 100 per cent prevention programme, where pigs were kept out of the residential area and drinking water and hand washing water was disinfected by keeping it in plastic bottles under the sun for 6 hours, proper sanitation arrangements, use of mosquito net and arrangement of vehicles for taking the patients to hospital. Early vaccination programme is also the part of the Holiya village formula.

[Byline: Arjumand Bano]

Communicated by:
ProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts
<promed@promedmail.org>

[No data are presented in the above report on the proposition of the 991 encephalitis cases in the area due to Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) infections or from other causes. The Holiya village EEM mentioned encephalitis cases due to enteroviruses in contaminated water. Previous reports from that area also associated encephalitis cases with contaminated water. However, revisiting the comments made by Dr T Jacob John, he mentioned that cases in this area early in the year may be due to a Reye-like syndrome. In a 24 Jun 2014 comment (ProMED-mail archive no. 20140625.2563561) concerning the Reye-like syndrome, he stated that "the disease is undoubtedly hypoglycemic encephalopathy (with blood glucose levels below 40 in about half the children in whom testing was done), and lower than 80 in 80-85 per cent. The lesson was to give 10 percent dextrose infusion as soon as possible after drawing blood for glucose measurement. Pediatricians who did this tell me that children given 10 percent dextrose within a short period of onset tend to recover within a few hours and are well to go home the next day." In another comment, he noted on 3 Aug 2014 (see ProMED-mail archive no. 20140804.2656983), "I understand that West Nile virus is also present in that region, and some AES [acute encephalitis syndrome] may indeed be West Nile encephalitis." He indicated that JEV cases occur later in the year during the typical JEV transmission season. The above report provides no information about the JEV vaccination status of the population in the affected areas, nor the number of cases laboratory confirmed as JEV infections.

Following the death of a 22-year-old woman from South West Garo Hills district [Meghalaya state, India] due to Japanese encephalitis [virus infection], the medical authorities have taken precautionary measures to confine the disease from spreading.

There are 37 confirmed cases of Japanese encephalitis in the state to date, official sources said today [29 Aug 2014].

The death of the woman was the 1st such instance in the state.

Joint Director of Health Services, in-charge integrated disease surveillance project, Dr RO Budnah today said that the woman died after she went home following treatment at Tura Civil Hospital.

The woman was diagnosed with Japanese encephalitis on 21 Aug [2014] and later admitted to the Tura Civil Hospital.

"There are as many as 37 confirmed cases of Japanese encephalitis and we are taking all precautionary measures so that the disease does not spread further to unaffected parts of the state," Dr Budnah said.

Ri-Bhoi district is the most affected with 16 confirmed cases, Dr Budnath added.

[Meghalaya state is in northeastern India, where Japanese encephalitis virus transmission occurs seasonally. The above report quotes health authorities as indicating that precautionary measures have been taken to halt spread of this virus disease, but does not indicate what those measures are. Possible measures include mounting a vaccination campaign, intensive public education to avoid mosquito bites, or vector control, which is much more difficult for these _Culex_ mosquitoes, which can occur over extensive areas. India is still in mid-virus transmission season, so additional cases can be expected in this region of India.

From: Martin Haditsch <m_haditsch@syscomp.de> [edited]


As to the vaccination considerations: for years I have been discussing and re-evaluating the aspect of including a time frame (may it be one stay or repetitive travels to endemic areas) into the decision making process: it simply makes no sense.

Japanese encephalitis (JE) is a (very) rare disease in travelers and there is no significant difference in between those who stay once or frequently, shorter or longer.

If the recommendations cited were applied half of the proven cases in travelers would not have been vaccinated -- this is like flipping a coin. Based on the fact that the infected mosquito simply does not ask: "How long are you already here?" or "Is it your 1st visit to this area?" before she bites and infects I would really ask the travel medicine community for support to impact national and international bodies responsible for official trail medicine advice with the goal of having a harmonized approach, which "allows" vaccination of those who want the shots no matter how long the stay, as well as taking the risk without vaccination in those who stay longer (for example, by applying the principle of guided self-responsibility).

Date: Wed 6 Aug 2014
Source: 7th Space [edited]
http://7thspace.com/headlines/478538/local_confirmed_case_of_japanese_encephalitis_under_chp_investigation.html


The Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health (DH) is today [6 Aug 2014] investigating a local confirmed case of Japanese encephalitis (JE) [virus infection], and hence urged the public to take precautions against mosquito-transmitted diseases.

The male patient, aged 36, with good past health, developed headache on 28 Jul [2014] and attended the Accident & Emergency Department (AED) of Tuen Mun Hospital (TMH) on 30 Jul [2014]. He was noted to have confused speech and seizures on 1 Aug [2014] and was taken to the AED of TMH again. He was admitted for further management on the same day. The patient is now afebrile in stable condition.

His cerebrospinal fluid and serum specimens tested positive for antibodies against JE [virus antigens] today [6 Aug 2014] upon laboratory testing by the CHP's Public Health Laboratory Services Branch.

Initial enquiries revealed that the patient lives in the quarters of Crossroads Foundation near Gold Coast, Tuen Mun, and had no recent travel history during the incubation period.

He could not recall any recent mosquito bites. His family contact has remained asymptomatic and will be put under medical surveillance. The CHP's investigations are ongoing.

Officers of the CHP will conduct home visits and surveys among neighbours of the patient's residence for active case finding and arranging of blood tests.

The CHP's hotline (2125 1122), set up for public enquiries since the 1st local confirmed JE case, will operate till 9 pm today and from 9 am to 6 pm from tomorrow (7 Aug 2014] onwards.

A health talk will be held at Crossroads Foundation this evening to deliver health advice to the public. Residents of Tuen Mun District with JE symptoms are also advised to promptly seek medical attention.

The CHP will issue letters to doctors and hospitals to draw their attention to the case and enlist their support in early diagnosis, control and prevention of JE.

This is the 4th JE case (3 local, one imported) reported to the CHP this year. In 2013, 6 cases (2 local, 3 imported, one unclassified) were reported in 2013 while 3 (one local, 2 imported) were filed in 2012.

"JE is a viral disease transmitted by the bite of infected mosquitoes. _Culex tritaeniorhynchus_ (culicine mosquito) is the principal vector of JE and is nocturnal. It mainly breeds in waterlogged fields, marshes, ditches, and small stagnant collections of water around cultivated fields. The mosquitoes become infected by feeding on pigs and wild birds infected with the JE virus, and then transmit the virus to humans and animals during the feeding process. JE is endemic on the Mainland and in Southeast Asia," a spokesman for the CHP explained.

Most JE virus infections are mild without apparent symptoms other than fever with headache. More severe infections are clinically characterised by the quick onset of headache, high fever, neck stiffness, impaired mental state, coma, tremors, occasional convulsions (especially in infants) and paralysis.

To avoid contracting JE, members of the public, particularly those living in rural areas, are reminded to take heed of the following preventive measures, especially after dark:
- wear loose, light-coloured, long-sleeved clothes and trousers;
- use effective insect repellents containing DEET over exposed parts of the body and clothing when outdoors; and
- use mosquito screens or nets in rooms which are not air-conditioned.

Travellers to endemic areas of JE should take the following precautions:
- avoid outdoor exposure to mosquito bites at dusk and dawn, especially in rural areas, when mosquitoes spreading this virus are most active;
- apply effective insect repellents containing DEET over exposed parts of the body and clothes; and
- consider vaccination and arrange a travel health consultation with a doctor to determine the need for vaccination and vector preventive measures at least 6 weeks before departure to endemic areas in Asia or the Western Pacific for stays of over one month, particularly in high-risk rural areas.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts
<promed@promedmail.org>

[As the report above indicates, there have been sporadic cases of Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) infection in Hong Kong (see ProMED-mail archives listed below). There have been 3 cases previously reported this year (2014) in Hong Kong. The virus is endemic in large areas of Asia, including Japan and China. Because Hong Kong is well within the geographic distribution of JEV, it would not be surprising to see additional cases occur occasionally. Individuals living in, or traveling to, JEV endemic areas are well advised to follow precautions to avoid mosquito bites. JEV vaccine is available in China, but there is no mention about the immunization status of the above 2014 cases, although there is a recommendation for people to be vaccinated if they are going to be in a high risk area for a month or more. The CHP has responded to this case with vigorous neighborhood action to detect and prevent additional cases.

Maps of Hong Kong can be seen at http://www.travelchinaguide.com/images/map/hongkong/hongkong-map.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/198. - Mod.TY]

The encephalitis outbreak in northern West Bengal has claimed one more life, taking the death toll in the entire state this year to 212, an official said Wednesday [13 Aug 2014].

According to BR Satpathi, director of state health services, 693 acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) cases were reported this year [2014] in the state. "As many as 212 deaths due to AES have occurred in Bengal since January. Of them, 44 died due to Japanese encephalitis (JE) [virus infection]," Satpathi told IANS. JE is a subset of AES caused by the mosquito-borne virus.

The number of deaths this year [2014] due to AES in north Bengal is 108, while 40 of them were due to JE. "There has been one death and 2 suspected cases of AES in the last one day," he said.

Encephalitis is a disease that results in inflammation of the brain, affecting the patient's central nervous system. It can be caused due to bacterial or viral infections of the brain, injection of toxic substances, or complications of an infectious disease.

While the lesser symptoms include headache and fever, the more severe ones cause the onset of mental issues like seizures, confusion, disorientation, tremors, and hallucinations.

For JE, while human beings are the dead-end hosts of the virus, pigs act as amplifying hosts that aid in spread of the disease [and birds, especially ardeids, are reservoirs of the virus. - Mod.TY]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts
<promed@promedmail.org>

[The number of AES cases and deaths in West Bengal continues to rise. Only 44 of the 212 deaths were attributed to JE virus infections. Revisiting the comments by Dr T Jacob John, the number of JE cases may be higher. Others early in the year may be due to a Reye-like syndrome. He noted, in his 3 Aug 2014 comment (see ProMED-mail archive no. 20140804.2656983), "Assam and the northern part of West Bengal are contiguous and traditionally Japanese encephalitis virus-enzootic areas." He continued, adding that, "the term acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) is used in the context of JE epidemics to denote encephalitis cases that are not laboratory confirmed for one reason or another. Thus, in Assam and West Bengal, the cases of JE and AES should be added up to see the real magnitude of the JE outbreak. I understand that West Nile virus is also present in that region, and some AES may indeed be West Nile encephalitis."

[1] India, Assam
Date: Wed 6 Aug 2014
Source: International Business Times [edited]
http://www.ibtimes.co.in/encephalitis-outbreak-assam-death-toll-rises-350-606183


The mosquito-borne disease [Japanese] encephalitis has taken more than 350 lives in Assam in the last few weeks. Japanese encephalitis (JE) and acute encephalitis syndrome outbreaks have affected 21 districts of Assam, with Sivasagar being the worst affected area.

More than 45 people have succumbed to the disease in Sivasagar alone this year [2014], despite it being the headquarters of the JE vaccination programme, which was started in 2011.

According to doctors, after the commencement of the programme, there was a shortage of vaccines for 2 consecutive years. There was insufficient supply to meet the demands, as the vaccines are produced only in China.

The state could not meet the demands sufficiently, despite receiving a grant of 910.4 crore [Rs 9 104 000 000, equal to USD 148 371 000] from the National Rural Health Mission in 2013. Out of the grant money, 57.41 crore [Rs 574 100 000, equal to USD 148 371 000] was specifically allotted to tackle vector-borne diseases, with a major part to be spent on encephalitis outbreak prevention.

Lack of special care units, laboratories and shortage of medicines for the treatment of encephalitis in district hospitals also reportedly played a part in the massive outbreak of the disease, killing hundreds in the last few weeks.

Meanwhile, 9 districts remained shielded from the encephalitis outbreak because of the vaccination programme in February [2014], according to NDTV.

Mosquitoes, the carriers of the virus, breed in stagnant water pits and paddy fields, areas most prone to JE. Having a moist climate, deep forests, and a dense network of water streams, Assam is highly prone to the disease.

[Byline: Neha Singh]

--

[2] India, West Bengal
Date: Tue 5 Aug 2014
Source: The Hindu [edited]
http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/kolkata/encephalitis-deaths-touch-206-govt-seeks-approval-for-adult-vaccination/article6283003.ece?homepage=true


With over 200 deaths reported because of acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) and Japanese encephalitis (JE) in West Bengal, the State government has urged the Centre to allow it to go in for an adult vaccination programme to arrest the disease. So far, vaccine has been administered only to children, and according to senior officials of the State Health Department, the cases of vaccinated children affected by the disease is almost nil.

"We have requested the Centre to enlighten us about the pilot project on the adult vaccination conducted in Assam. If the Centre allows us to go ahead, we are ready to vaccinate people," BR Satpathy, Director of Health Services, told The Hindu on Monday [4 Aug 2014].

According to the latest figures available with the Health Department, so far 206 persons have died of AES and JE in the State since January 2014. Of the 206 deaths, 37 are because of JE.

Dr. Satpathy said 92 deaths have occurred in the State in less than a month since 7 Jul 2014, after the outbreak was reported in north Bengal. Of the 92 deaths, 28 are because of JE, he said.

Despite attempts by the State government to contain the spread of encephalitis in north Bengal over the past few days, there have been reports of the mosquito-borne disease spreading to districts of south Bengal as well.

Senior health officials admitted that at least 2 deaths have been reported in the districts of south Bengal. While a child died of acute encephalitis syndrome in Bankura district on Sunday [3 Aug 2014], days ago, a person had died of Japanese encephalitis in Murshidabad district.

The State unit of the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) has accused the State government of not taking any help from the Centre to tackle the disease despite the Union Health Ministry extending all its support in the matter.

The BJP MP from Darjeeling, SS Ahulwalia, and Congress MP from Berhampore Adhir Ranjan Chowdhury raised the issue of encephalitis deaths in Parliament on Sunday [3 Aug 2014] and pointed out that the State government has done little to contain the disease.

Meanwhile, another senior health official faced the State government's ire in connection with the outbreak. Anup Roy, Principal of North Bengal Medical College and Hospital (NBMCH), which is dealing with a bulk of patients affected by AES and JE, was suspended on Monday [4 Aug 2014].

Earlier, 3 senior health officials -- medical superintendent of NBMCH and chief medical officer of health of Darjeeling and Jalpaiguri districts -- were suspended by the Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee, who holds the health portfolio.

[Byline: Shiv Sahay Singh]

Encephalitis and meningitis have spread to most areas of the northern province of Son La, affecting more than 100 children and killing 13 of them so far this year [2014], health authorities reported on Tuesday [5 Aug 2014].

[Unfortunately, the above report does not indicate what proportions of the more than 100 cases are due to JE virus infections and to meningitis. However, the sample of 73 cases laboratory tested indicated that 42 per cent were due to JE virus infections. This is not surprising, since Viet Nam has had active JE virus transmission this year (2014). Most cases of Japanese encephalitis there occur in the south during the rainy and early dry season, shifting to the north of the country during late summer and autumn. Nationally, 73 per cent of the population lives in areas of risk to JE virus infection.

Wild birds, especially ardeids, are reservoirs of JEV. Pigs are amplifying hosts. Several _Culex_ mosquito species are efficient vectors of the virus, transmitting the virus among wild birds and pigs and to humans. Vaccination and avoidance of mosquito bites are the only measures available to avoid infection and disease.
